narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid--you were great at explaining concepts that Ann could not get across!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse met my expectations of a teaching assistant.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was a very good TA and was very knowledgeable about all subjects relating to the material.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Very helpful
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse D
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse made herself very available if we needed her.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Q: 7, 8& 9: The Harvard trip was a bit of a let down. It was too far to mainly just look at the dioramas. I would rather have taken a trip locally and viewed/identified stand development. The other field trips were excellent.

The lectures and readings only covered a limited range of knowledge about the subject material. Although we repeatedly acknowledged that several of the concepts were antiquated, we continued to base the course upon them. Readings were too general.

The field trips were great except for the Harvard forest one. It was more focused on taxonomy and it was a long drive for very little field interaction and very little learning.I think the content of the course was really important. I felt like a had a good handle on it by the end due to strong instruction and a solid TA. However, making more of a connection betweenthe reading and the lecture is really important. Some of the reading was a bit denseit would have beengood to get more ofa guide through it in addition to discussion time. Also, I think that certain parts of the OliverLarson could be required justto have more material tosupport slides.Was sorry to miss the student presentations.Other than that Anne is a delight!

Q11: Ann responds to student questions, but at time is very derisive of student questions/comments, I think without realizing it. This undercuts rapport with students, and shuts down some students' willingness to participate in class, for fear of being wrong and vehemently told so.Q12: Test questions and test post-mortem process are quite problematic; mid-term should be as diverse as the final in question type (mult. choice, T/F, matching, fill-in-blank), and questions shouldn't be designed to trick students but rather straightforwardly test material and concepts to be mastered. Develop new questions so students can learn from the kind of complicated questions Ann poses, in studying for the final. In other classes professors hand back the printout exams with the questions right there, and seem to have no concerns with cheating; on the contrary, this helps students feel much more confident for subsequent exams and suggests that the professor is not trying to trick them.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The readings were good although not all were equally valuable. The powerpoints were also very useful and we reviewed a large number of concepts. The course provides a good introduction to forest ecology and silviculture.

The course's progression was logical and concepts were clearly explained. I think the assigned readings were very relevant and helpful in understanding the development of forest stand dynamic theory since its inception.Beyond that, Ann Camp is a friendly person.

The readings were very helpful, as well as to have the powerpoint lectures beforehand--there's no way I could have taken all my notes just in class. The field trips were good but there could have been more, maybe more like your Taxonomy field trips of just walking around and getting a sense of how things are.
Very informative. The other two field trips w/ Tom Wessels and to Great Mtn. were excellent.
field trips
Field trips.
Outclass reading
Discussions of old growth and deep time
The field trip with Tom Wessels was excellent and the group discussions were engaging.
Using primary literature to reinforce basic class concepts
Breadth and depth of concepts coveredPractical applicationRelevant and seminal papers assigned

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The field trip to the Harvard Forest was quite a letdown and I don't think it should be renewed next year; it just takes too much time for too small an amount of added educational value.On a more constructive note, I would love to see some homework added to the class. Small, applied weekly problem sets would be very helpful.

Ann struggled to explain things sometimes. She couldn't re-word in order to try to get her point across--we were expected to get inside her brain which is not practical. She had expectations for us that were not expressed until taking the midterm.

I would have liked to do a bit more in the field looking at stands and attempting to discern what was happening. Maybe like a quiz or no points quiz or something where we all write down what we think is happening and try to identify different strata, and dominant/codominant/intermediate/suppressed trees and say what is most likely outcompeting what. Also would be nice to look at this along different site gradients too.
presentation of informationmore encouraging discussion environmentneed adequate textbook for referencelearning objectives for each field trip should be identified
Expanded range of readings, improved class discussion, more effective communication from the professor.
connecting reading to lecture
The lectures could get very tedious at times, somehow incorporating more student engagement would be helpful.

I found the readings very useful but I feel like more structured discussions would have reinforced the content. Perhaps a short intro section (~10min) to give historical and academic context to the assigned readings would have been a useful way to start and frame the discussions.

Principally, the candor of the class environment: avoiding derisive responses to student comments so that students continue to feel comfortable participating.Mechanisms to encourage discussion participation even from quiet students (such as splitting class into small-group discussions, in-class small-group problem sets based on contents of readings, student-leader assignment for discussions, etc.)Fairer test questions and scoring: exhorts brief answers to test questions, but knocks points off a good answer for forgetting obscure details.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I liked the discussions, it took us the first one to understand the idea and afterwards we got a lot out of them. But I think they could be greatly improved if they were more structured instead of waiting for students to give their opinion about the readings. Make them more challenging, more critical, with more questions.
See above.
less effectiveless abrasive environment for discussion recommended

Discussions were poor - professor did not know how to stimulate class participation. Most importantly, the professor needs to arrive to discussion with a list of questions regarding the readings, rather than merely asking, "what did you think about this reading?"
maybe mail out guiding discussion questions prior to classes to guide conversation constructively
Yes, I liked having 2-3 lectures then a discussion. It tied the material together well.
Effective. Discussion improvement ideas described above.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: awesome review sessions, personal experience, sometimes her schedule wasdifficult and inconsistent for one on one review but group sessions hugely helpful
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Great TA! Helped to explain conceptual material in a clear way and organized several review sessions.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is a great T.A. and I recommend her to repeat her role for this class next year.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was awesome and accessible and knowledgeable. She could really explain things when Ann could not.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  I thought Marlyse did an excellent job leading the discussion. The first exam review was excellent as well, the second not so much but the students also did not ask very specific questions either... Lecture was interesting.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  helpful review sessionsinsightful commentsenjoyed presentation on understory
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was very effective and could provide examples and explain concepts well.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marcuse was an excellent teaching instructor who is very reachable and helpful.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was a great contributor to the course due to the relevance of her research to some of the topics and her existing supplementary knowledge of understory plants. She was very good at noticing students' sticking points and offering clarifications in class or in review sessions. A minor point of constructive feedback is that during the understory plant lecture she seemed to stick a little too much to the slides and could have perhaps engaged with the class a bit more.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse contributed a lot to class, helping clarify many points and bringing her own expertise. She was organized and helpful, but sometimes didn't know herself what Ann was looking for in, for example, review questions, test questions, etc. This does not suggest a lack of knowledge or professionalism on Marlyse's part, but rather indicates a need for better TA-prof communication and collaboration.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Provides a good introduction to forest ecology and will be useful for Mark's silviculture class. It was the first time I learned about this subject and, while I know that some of my classmates were frustrated with the level of detail provided, I think that the class serves its purpose.
It is a required course for spring's Silviculture with Prof. Ashton.
This class will definitely help before taking Silviculture with Mark Ashton.
I think this course is basic prep for the Forestry track, and has quite a lot to offer the other tracks as well in terms of gaining knowledge about forest processes.
Very applicable. Basic requirement for all persons who desire careers related to forest management.
The course should provide a foundation of forest ecology and dynamics for MF and MFS students, but the readings and lectures were too simplified and the examples were few.
i wanted to learn how forests grow - i had no idea before this course
This course is a critical component to my overall program at FES. It would be impossible to study forests in any effective manner without this course.
The course is a key component of the Master of Forestry curriculum and provides valuable knowledge generally of how forests change and evolve. This is critical to any resource manager.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Well, because I'm an MF. The true question is why did some students not take this course.
Stand dynamics is interesting.
Recommended introduction to Silviculture
To understand forest processes and prepare for the Forestry track.
Prerequisite / foundation for future silviculture courses.
See 20.
Learning theory
I am extremely interested in forest management, so this course is a necessity for that field of study.
I wanted to get an introduction to the workings of forests and also be better prepared for more advanced courses such as Silviculture.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I think they did!
Yes.
Mostly, I don't feel like I can really apply a lot of what I learned but hopefully that will develop as I continue the MF program.
Yes.
Yes and no.Some areas such as quantitative anaylsis of growth and yield were so superficial that it seemed pointless.
No - Greater breadth of material was necessary.Research assignment should not have been cancelled.
Yes
Yes, I have a great understanding of the material.

Absolutely. The course gives a solid theoretical foundation of the way trees and (to a lesser extent) understory plants interact. Highlights were the findings from palynology and our revised knowledge of disturbance regimes (e.g., fire is important and necessary).
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Would have been a good idea.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings seriously before each class, you'll get much more out of it. Don't hesitate to ask questions even if you get shut down (you will be), Ann knows a lot but you have to actively tap her knowledge.
Going over the slides before class is helpful and the readings are great.
Read the powerpoints before class! Ask Marlyse for help with anything.
Do the readings and ask questions.
The information presented is critical for persons with interest in forest management,yet the style of presentation is not for everyone.

Don't -The course felt like intro college forest stands rather than a Masters level course with higher level synthesis that expands on the breadth of the student's backgrounds.The course might be more helpful for MF and MFS students with little background in forest ecology.
Read more
I would certainly take this course if you are interested in forest science or management.
This is a solid introductory course to how forests work and gives great perspective, even if you are not an MF.
